pageContext.claim: “We've gotten rid of vocational schools and we've replaced them with community colleges.”
pageContext.analysis: This is a puzzling statement by the president, but in the past Trump has indicated he's confused about the difference between vocational schools and community colleges. Vocational, or trade schools, have traditionally offered hands-on training related to a particular career, often but not exclusively in high school. The length of vocational programs varies, and they usually require internships. Two-year community colleges provide many of the same features as four-year colleges, including wide curricular offerings in different subjects and, sometimes, clubs and sports events. Many students get a two-year community college degree – with a core curriculum – and then transfer to a four-year college for a bachelor’s degree.
